newsitem.title: USA: Kellogg Q3, full-year results to be down.
newsitem.headline: Kellogg Q3, full-year results to be down.

text.p: Kellogg Co said Wednesday that its decision to slash cereal prices will lower third quarter earnings by about 20 percent below the $1.05 a share it earned a year ago, not including the impact of non-recurring events.
Kellogg said it expects earnings will return to growth in the fourth quarter. But full-year earnings will be less than the $3.48 a share it posted for all of 1995.
Kellogg said it remains committed to its strategy of reducing inefficient promotion spending in the U.S. ready-to-eat cereal business, which it has done while also cutting cereal prices.

"We continue to believe this is the best long-term strategy to deliver more value for consumers, promote category growth and achieve superior returns for Kellogg stockholders," Arnold Langbo, chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement.
"We will continue to direct our efforts away from deep price promotion; however, we are unwilling to see our leadership position compromised," Langbo said.
"Our fourth quarter results will be influenced significantly by competitive conditions in the category at that time," he added.

Analysts have been questioning whether the cereal giant could hit the $3.48 figure of a year ago. Kellogg said in late July that it expected 1996 earnings to be about the same as 1995, excluding charges.
